I do have hyperhydrosis, and used to get Botox injections for this-for anyone that suffers from this condition, I highly recommend Botox if you can get it. The effects normally last about 6 months, and many insurance providers are covering this now (I can't get it at the moment because I am waiting to get in to a doctor in my area that actually does it to treat this). If you can't get Botox, and want something for those special occasions or times when deodorant/antiperspirant just won't work on their own, I would give this a try. Wish it cost less for the few applications that you get, but still worth it. The one thing I didn't read on the package was how long you were supposed to hold the wipe on your skin. I did about 45 seconds or so under each arm, but not sure if that matters? Something either I missed or they should put on the directions.

  128. Of all the reviews I have ever left on Amazon, this one has to be not only one of the earliest postings after receiving the product, but also one of the most satisfying to write. I want to start off by saying that surprisingly, I don't sweat under my arms excessively, ever. In fact I don't really sweat under my arms at all. I can work outside all day and use some dollar store brand of anti perspirant and come away at the end of a hot day with at the most, a slight dampness under my arms. It's truly the only place on my body where I don't sweat. I wouldn't have any use for this product if that was the end of the story, but its not. My problem is sweating on the face and forehead. Even in a situation where it is rather cool and dry and everyone around me seems to be comfortably settled in with dry hair and faces, it at times can be pouring off me, sometimes relentlessly, for hours even. Anyone that has ever had such a problem well knows how embarrassing and unsightly this can be. Any \\"solution\\" to the problem in the past ran the gamut of stuffing my pockets with paper towels to just making excuses for not showing up for some event or whatever when you know its going to be unbearably hot. Over the years I have tried many drug store brands of so called super powered sweat controlling anti perspirants just to have them be relentlessly ineffective and a waste of money. It is, and has been a problem that I thought up till now had no solution. Then I discovered Sweat Block..<br /><br />Sweat Block, (SB) has been so effective for me for this problem that it almost qualifies as a miracle drug. In fact its only by the favor of excessive sweating never actually killing anyone that keeps it out of that miraculous category. SB is nothing more than some highly concentrated formula of aluminum chloride or something or other that is found in many anti perspirants. But trust me, the similarity ends there. They don't work,....This does, fantastically. The box comes with 8 sealed towelettes that are soaked with the formula that you tear open and dab on your skin. It's clear, near odorless, and dries in a jiffy. Just to get the facts straight, SBs instructions clearly state that it's for \\"underarms only\\". But after reading the dazzling reviews of this stuff here I just couldn't resist. I figured the worst that could happen is that I would lose $20 and end up looking like the sweating slob I always do under the mildest of conditions. From the very first morning after applying it, it was obvious that this stuff was as superbly effective as most of the glowing reviews here attest too. I simply stopped sweating, period. When pushed to the limit of activity or heat, a slight dampness or \\"sheen\\" would appear on my face that was not at all long lasting, nor embarrassing. I felt like a new man. I have been actually going out of my way to sweat and enjoying the dryness that I am so unfamiliar with. It is important that you use this product as described in the directions. Your underarms/head should be dry, and remain dry for at least 3 hours after application. (Which is the reason why they recommend applying it just before bed). Given these simple rules, I can only tell you this stuff is as effective and satisfying as anything I can ever remember purchasing in a personal hygiene category. As for being a renegade and using it on my forehead and face as opposed to my underarms, I can only tell you that personally I have suffered absolutely no tingling, redness, rash, or anything else detrimental with my alternative use. Despite Sweat Blocks explicit but simply stated warning that its for underarm use only, I feel compelled to recommend it to anyone that suffers such a problem as I do. (And I know I am far from alone with it). It's worth a shot and one time expense, I promise you.<br /><br />One last helpful hint. As stated already, SB comes in sealed packets as a moist towelette. I don't know if its that my forehead or face issmaller than a pair of underarms, or that I am just cheaper than the average Joe in trying to use the towelettes twice. But in any event, I have learned that dabbing my face with the pads and then just resealing the still moist towelette inside the packets again tightly with tape or a paper clip has afforded me double the use of each pad, with no reduction in its effectiveness. I simply tear open the packet, apply, reseal it, and then use the same towelette 5 days later and one box lasts near 16 weeks instead of 8. (Like a lot of others here, I like the 5 day rule of reapplication instead of the promised seven, just to make sure). This may not work for all people depending on how bad your sweating problem is. But for me personally, double use has just added an extra smile of satisfaction to an already stunningly effective product. This cost saving (cheap) test run on yourself may be very much worth trying as well. In conclusion, whether your problem with sweating is on your face or head, or just the sentimental favorite underarms, I give Sweat Block my highest recommendation. This product has been a Godsend to me, and it just may be to you too... : )smaller than a pair of underarms, or that I am just cheaper than the average Joe in trying to use the towelettes twice. But in any event, I have learned that dabbing my face with the pads and then just resealing the still moist towelette inside the packets again tightly with tape or a paper clip has afforded me double the use of each pad, with no reduction in its effectiveness. I simply tear open the packet, apply, reseal it, and then use the same towelette 5 days later and one box lasts near 16 weeks instead of 8. (Like a lot of others here, I like the 5 day rule of reapplication instead of the promised seven, just to make sure). This may not work for all people depending on how bad your sweating problem is. But for me personally, double use has just added an extra smile of satisfaction to an already stunningly effective product. This cost saving (cheap) test run on yourself may be very much worth trying as well. In conclusion, whether your problem with sweating is on your face or head, or just the sentimental favorite underarms, I give Sweat Block my highest recommendation. This product has been a Godsend to me, and it just may be to you too... : )

  131. I sweat profusely on my face, and always have. It didn't matter if it was 50 degrees and I was moving around, or if it was 80 degrees and I was standing still in the shade. I work in customer service, so it's always been really embarrassing to have sweat running down my face when I'm just standing there helping a customer. I'm on my first week of Sweat Block, and so far it's worked wonders. I know that it specifies under arm usage, but the first wipe I used, I ran it all over my face, behind my neck, and on my throat. I have extremely sensitive skin, so I was nervous, but the only reaction I had was a slight 'tightness' and a very slight prickling sensation the next morning. This week has been in the 90s, and I've actually been able to put my makeup on and keep it in place! I've also noticed that since I've barely had any sweat on my face and neck, I don't feel as hot. Go figure. I can feel myself getting flushed and warm, but when I reach up to my face and neck, there's barely any dampness there at all. I always research products before I buy them, but seldom get around to writing reviews. This has worked so well for me that I wanted to let others in my situation know that there is an alternative to constantly looking like you've been running a marathon, especially when everyone else around you looks cool and dry! I'm really grateful that I found this product, and I intend to keep using it! ***UPDATE***I have been using SweatBlock for nearly a month now. Unfortunately, after the first use, which was incredible, the product ceased to work for me. I haven't done anything different when applying to my face each week, so I'm not sure exactly what the issue is. The end of the first week, the product started to wear off, so I applied as I had the first time. I'm really dissapointed, because it was wonderful not to constantly have to wipe the sweat from my face and neck. I still have 4 pads left, but I don't think I'll bother applying any more...

They're still working for me. I'm able to go a full week, sometimes longer, on one application and no sweat coming through my shirts.<br /><br />Follow up 1/2/2013 - bumped to 5 stars. It would shorten the life of my shirts and increase the amount of time spent doing laundry because I would always have to pretreat and scrub the underarm areas in order to prevent or delay permanent staining. I would have to constantly switch anti-perspirant/deodorants because my body would develop a tolerance within a few months and render them ineffective. I had better success using the Certain-Dri system, but it didn't eliminate all of my problems. I tried Sweatblock because of its promise to \\"eliminate underarm sweating for up to 7 days.\\" I bought it figuring I had nothing to lose, except the money paid to purchase it, and all the more to gain. After using the product for about a month now, I would like to share my findings. Pros: Directions are easy to follow Product is easy to apply Comes with an 8 week supply Stops excessive underarm sweating Reduced the amount of time spent on laundry Website that contains additional information on the product as well as answers to Frequently Asked Questions Cons: Did not personally experience the \\"up to 7 day guarantee\\" Experienced a mild tacky/sticky feeling in my underarms at times when I would normally be sweating excessively Money back guarantee only applies to product purchased from Sweatblock website So you may be asking, \\"Why did you give this product 5 stars?\\" First of all, I average about 5-6 days of dryness after applying the product. Because I am not sweating excessively any more, I have become less self conscious about my appearance and don't worry about people staring at me when I am in public. This \\"mental relief\\" has allowed me to become more confident when I am out and about. Second, this is the only product I have tried that has been able to completely stop my excessive underarm sweating problem. Because I don't sweat anymore, I don't have to spend extra time pretreating the underarms of my shirt prior to laundering them. This also helps to reduce the use of laundry soaps which saves me money. Now I want to make this abundantly clear. I have described my own personal experiences using this product. Your experience with this product may be different from mine as no two people are exactly the same. Also, the price of the product may be a turn off to some, but in my mind, the money saved by extending the life of your clothes and reducing the amount of laundry soaps used to clean them, helps offset the purchase price. I will also mention that even though it stopped my excessive sweating, I still had to use deodorant to combat body odor. Again, your results may vary. You may also become more aware of other places you sweat which can take a little time getting used too. Overall, I would recommend this product to anyone who suffers from excessive underarm sweating, especially if they have tried various other anti-perspirants like I have with similar results. I am certainly satisfied with the results and you might be as well if you give this product a shot.

I have no qualms with sweating when I exercise. I do hate it when I dress for a business meeting and walk outside to the car or use transit then I start to sweat. I have been checked by 3 doctors over the years. I don't have any biological issues that cause me to sweat a lot. I don't have anxiety attacks. Not taking any strange medications. I consume primarily 70% veggies, fruits & raw nuts. I eat a lot of fish and a steak once a week. I just cannot tolerate humidity. I don't sweat on my hands, soles of my feet and only mildly in my private area unless I have run a good 6 miles at lunchtime outdoors.<br /><br />This product is a miracle. The simple act of sitting outside in a swing or going to Piedmont Park to have a picnic without looking like a mass murderer is running after me is no longer an issue. I can go to the outdoor festivals around town without leaving by 11 AM or going around 5 PM.I can wear a summer lightweight blazer outdoors to my car or an event where there is AC and not have my make up melt in 5 or 10 minutes. I have flawless skin DUE TO EASILY SWEATING. Yes, like most women we have no desire to sweat or have people think we are nervous at a party or event. Sweat Block has giving me a new lease on life.<br /><br />It takes my body about 10-15 minutes to cool down once I enter an air conditioned environment. Being out in the hot sun for small amounts of time like 5 to 10 minutes can RUIN my MAKEUP and usually my mild disposition. I sleep.<br /><br />In the morning I use my regular Secret on my underarms. I mist my body with water and apply my mixture of sunscreen and scented body lotion. I place my facial sunblock on after washing my face. If I run in the morning I shower normally after my run then moisturize my face and body as I would normally do. The SWEAT BLOCK doesn't lose its effectiveness either way.<br /><br />I save the towelette in a Ziploc bag place in the fridge so I get 2 uses out of ONE towelette. I have used Block Sweat since April. It works for me every 4 days in Atlanta spring and summer months. If I go to California or overseas where there is low humidity I did not need Sweat Block at all. Once I return to Atlanta I have to immediately use it the evening of my return. I will get a mild sweat but still annoying if I don't use the towelette by the 5th or 6th day.<br /><br />I started working from home recently so I still use Sweat Block so I don't look haggard when I go outside in the heat doing errands. I can walk from my new condo to the grocery store (literally an 8 minute walk) in the heat during theNoon hour and not SWEAT! I can walk to the AMC movie theater from my place which is a 11 minute walk in the spring and summer without a DROP OF SWEAT! I still look cute once I enter the air-conditioned theater or store. I don't have to waste time looking for a parking space close to the entrance of the mall. I know you guys and girls are laughing at me but those of us with perspiration issues know the pain & embarrassment of people asking IS THERE ANYTHING WRONG? ARE YOU OKAY? WOULD YOU LIKE SOME WATER?   368. As another customer mentioned, it does stop working after about a week of usage. This like a lot of other antiperspirants contains aluminum chloride (high levels), which is fine. But the problem for a lot of people is their bodies become resistant to the aluminum chloride, and the product stops working. So, for some it may work long-term. For others probably not for long. But, it was nice not having to worry for a few days.

  373. It's an unavoidable scenario, I suppose. But, the levels of some products' active ingredients in what used to be considered \\"clinical strength\\" versions have slowly become replaced by higher and higher levels. In just the past decade, antiperspirant products (like Sweat Block) that contain 14% active ingredient, have started to lose their place in the market with the introduction of products with 17%, 19%, and even 20%; and, all of these have been made available in big-chain stores located in every major town. Maybe it's a case of biological resistance-building to the ingredients or maybe it's a great marketing strategy for huge corporations to corner the market...but, Sweat Block, although it does FANTASTICLY the job it claims, might soon get pushed off the shelves by products with higher percentages in their ingredient lists. Unfortunate. But, it's a reality. Sweat Block works GREAT for me, so I'll continue to use it.

Over the years I've used different products, such as Certain Dry, Clinical Antiperspirants, Klima and Drysol. I have to say, I'm not impressed with Sweat Block. I'm on my 2nd week of using Sweat Block--applying one pad per week as directed after showering/drying armpits/before bed. On week 1, Sweat Block (when used alone) only stopped my armpit sweat for 1 day!!! Week 2 so far: Friday Night: applied sweat block Day 1 of Sweat Block + deodorant/antiperspirant. Brisk walking/Jog for 20 minutes + walk around NYC all day = no pit stains the entire day, but I did notice some sweating when I touched my armpits after jogging Day 2: I applied deodorant/antiperspirant. Leisure day. Noticed very minor sweating. Day 3: I applied deodorant/antiperspirant. Leisure day. Armpit sweat was suppressed by about 50%. Day 4: I applied deodorant/antiperspirant. Leisure day. Felt like my armpit was back to its original state. I'm going to try using Sweat Block 2 nights in a row on my Week 3 to see if that will fix the problem. If that is the case, I will probably not purchase this product again since 1 box will only last me a month. The main reason for this purchase was because it claimed that you only have to apply it 1X/wk unlike Certain Dry and all the other products. Anyway, out of all the products I've used, I think Drysol worked the best for me. It does sting the most, but I only have to use that 2X a week, it keeps me dry for an entire week and the bottle lasts almost 3 months.

The real test will come when the high temperatures and 95% humidity hit here on the east coast in a few months, but judging by what I've experience up to this point, I'm feeling fairly confident about SBs ability to hold up against them.<br /><br />I've given the product 4 out of 5 stars because the stinging sensation when applied is, at least for me, fairly significant. However, any potential purchaser should maybe keep in mind that I'm using the product outside of it's recommended use, and that since facial skin is generally more tender than underarm skin, the sensation may be much less pronounced there, if experienced at all.<br /><br />One last thing: As one of the places that the sweating on my face is localized is my temples, I've found it very useful to extend application of SB to at least an inch past my hairline directly above them. Within minutes of dressing each morning, her clothes were saturated and we used every product imaginable to get the odor out of her clothes and nothing worked. By entering high school, the odor in her clothes was so offensive and no prescription product the pediatrician had her use worked. We went to a dermatologist who offered very expensive Botox injections at $1000/3 months that insurance would not pay for - so not an option. Finally she offered a Rx pill that acted in a way that dried out her entire body and that worked - but she had a very extreme reaction and lost 80 pounds due to this drug causing a shut down of her digestive system and 5 doctors could not figure out that this drug was the culprit until we found the right doctor who immediately realized what the problem was. She was taken off of this obviously and then we were totally desperate and felt that there were no other options other than a risky surgery and that would have its own set of negative drawbacks. Then we found Sweat Block. I was completely in doubt that it would work since nothing else ever had. With the first application, my daughter noticed a substantial reduction in her sweat. That first week she used the second one a little sooner than a week apart as directed. Now, she has been using it for about 18 months and only needs to use it every 7 days!! Her sweating is totally under control. There is no more odor in her clothes whatsoever and she socially has her life back. I am amazed at how well this has worked and so thankful that we found it. It is so good, in fact, that we tell everyone we know who has a loved one with this embarrassing issue about the product and they love it as well.

Definitely give it a try if you're sick of sweaty arm pits and see if it works well enough for you.<br /><br />On another note, I noticed no skin irritation at all.<br /><br />Hope it helps.

I color my hair, so that really kind of eliminated my bravery at using this product on my scalp. However, I have used it on my face. The results are phenomenal. No more embarassing dripping when I break out into a hot flash or when it is really hot out. It is easy to use. At night, I dab it all over my face, around the hairline, and literally all over (being careful to avoid my eyes). I allow it to dry, and I make sure I don't sleep on my face or rub off the product. Starting the next day, no sweating. It lasts me about four to five weeks, and then I reapply. Downsides: a) I don't particularly like the smell; b) the fingers that hold the pad become rather dry; c) my face stings and is a bit itchy (which apparently happens to underarms too), and d) my face does dry out. I found that I had multiple dry spots all over my face, but I moisturized heavily, used a scrub, and after two days it was fine. I just reordered the product, and I know it will become a part of my regular routine. It simply works, and after years of embarassment, I am so thankful to not be dealing with the sweat.<br /><br />UPDATE: Something has changed. This time of year (April) I can go at least a week before needing to reapply the Sweat Block. In the summer it can sometimes be less than that. I definitely recommend this to anyone who sweats a lot!!!<br /><br />The only reason I am not giving it 5 stars is because you have to keep your arms up for 5 minutes after applying. Weird and possibly a little awkward, but well worth it!

  644. As with at least one of the other reviewers here, my sweating issue is NOT with the underarms, but with other locations. In my case it's my torso, face, and general head area.<br /><br />I sweat so much that I must bring a second uniform top to the karate dojo. My top gets so soaked with sweat that it (seriously) looks as though I've dumped water over my head. It's pretty gross, and understandably, no one likes to work with you (especially for holds / grappling) when you're that soaked.<br /><br />SweatBlock helps to reduce the sweat enough that I usually do not need to change my top for the second hour of practice. I still bring it \\"just in case\\", but I haven't had to swap out the top in quite some time. That's not to say that the top of the uniform does not get wet with sweat. Of course it does, just not so bad that I'm splashing my unfortunate partner.<br /><br />I do still need to wear a headband or else I sweat enough that I can make the floor slick, particularly when we're training on the wooden floor. Sweatblock does not help me with this, but a headband prevents problems for the other students. Oh if only SB made conditioner for the shower!<br /><br />How I apply Sweatblock:<br /><br />* Shoulders / upper back first<br />* Neck<br />* Arms (including hands)<br />* Torso (chest & belly area)<br />* Face<br />* Under arms if there is anything remaining on the towelette<br /><br />I do have sensitive skin, so SB makes my face and neck tingle and itch for awhile after I've applied it. I just have to bear with it until it passes, which usually is not a big deal. I have not had redness or any other visual signs of irritation.<br /><br />For day-to-day life, Sweatblock is useful for these hot days when I need to walk around campus or other public locations. If you thought that wet underarms were embarrassing, try having the front and back of your shirt soaked that way. That's just no fun at all. Sweatblock helps to prevent this problem.<br /><br />I sometimes wonder if I should just move to the south pole.etimes wonder if I should just move to the south pole.

  647. I have struggled with hyperhidrosis for a long while. I can soak the armpit of my shirt while sitting still in freezing weather. It is miserable. I could only wear certain colors or be embarrassed with huge soaking wet pit stains in public. This stuff works for me. If I am running around I still sweat under my arms, but it's like being a normal person now. If I am not exercising, my pits stay dry. If you are going to shave (men or women) DO NOT put this on the same night you shave. Also, dab it on like they say or you will have very irritated pits. Putting it on just before bed is also absolutely essential to getting long lasting results. I haven't tried going a full seven days yet but after five days I was still dry so I recommend trying this product if you suffer from embarrassing underarm sweating.

  649. I'm a 20 year old girl and come from a family of very heavy sweaters. Ever since I started buying my own clothes (middle-school), I always had to think \\"how bad will my pit-stains look in this shirt?\\" Sure enough, most of my closet is black or other very-dark colors. Recently, my oldest brother got engaged and I was a bridesmaid. As soon as I tried on the dress that the bride picked out for us, I knew my sweatstains would look horrendous. That was when I started going nuts trying to find a way to stop sweating so much. \\"Clinical Strength\\" antiperspirants/deodorants were not working as well as I hoped. I was wearing sanitary pads in my shirts for work so I wouldn't ruin my blouses!<br /><br />Thankfully, I found a mention about Sweatblock in a blog and looked it up. At first, I was tentative because sweating is a natural process and it couldn't be safe to stop it. But Sweatblock only stops sweat in the areas you apply it, and it is only temporary. It is basically just very concentrated antiperspirant.<br /><br />I took a note from another reviewer and after I use a towelette once, I put it back in the packet and close it tightly with scotch tape. Four or five days later, I use the same towelette again. This way I not only stay drier longer, but I make each packet last longer than a week. Now in the directions, it suggests applying it every seven days. I notice about day four or five I start sweating at unexpected times(not nearly as much as before, but more than preferred), so I don't usually go more than five days without reapplying. At first, there is some irritation, but I bought a gentler deodorant (Secret or Dove are nice) to use the first 2 days after I apply Sweatblock so I don't get so much irritation. On day 3 I return to my Clinical Strength Mitchum which is the best antiperspirant I have been able to find. Also, I find I only need to use regular antiperspirant once a day as opposed to the three or four times I was forced to use it before.<br /><br />Some people have mentioned the way Sweatblock smells when you apply it. I'll admit, it doesn't smell like flowers, but it only lasts until you shower the following morning and it really does not compare with the effectiveness of the product. By the way neither does the price! (Especially when you buy two boxes at once and get free amazon shipping).<br /><br />I tell everyone in my family about it because we all share the same \\"sweat genes\\" and every family photo is ridden with sweat stains! My oldest brother makes jokes now because it's not uncommon for me to say something and finish the sentence with, \\"but that was before Sweatblock, now I don't have that problem at all!\\" It is exciting to say that I now have a LOT more colors in my wardrobe as well as different materials and *gasp* long sleeve shirts that aren't hoodies! It's a cliche, I know, but Sweatblock really has had a major influence on my confidence and every-day comfort. I suggest it to absolutely everyone that sweats like a maniac.

  700. I didn't think I could keep it on, and considered washing it off, but I applied my moisturizer after about ten minutes, and that helped. This morning, my face felt a little tight, sort of like wearing a primer meant to mattify skin, but after I washed it it felt normal. I applied my products and makeup and went about my day, and my face did not sweat once! I cannot explain how happy this makes me. This product has changed my life. I can walk around in one layer confidently without being self-conscious around girls. Also very useful for interviews!<br /><br />I gave it four stars however because I can't say it completely eliminated the problem. When the instructions are followed to the point, it will block all my underarm sweat on the average day for 6 days. (On the 7th, some sweat comes through, but not enough to dampen my day.) But the instructions need to be followed precisely! One week I didn't air dry my armpits after applying the solution and the product only worked about 50% as efficiently. And on extremely intense days, either when I'm working out extra hard or have a stressful test, a some sweat may force it's way through. If this product could block sweat even on the rough days, it would have my 5 stars. But those are the only cons I have. The product does irritate a little the night you apply it but I don't find it a major annoyance. The product doesn't seem to wash off or lose effectiveness as the week wears on as promised (minus the 7th day decrease in effectiveness.)<br /><br />Overall I am extremely pleased with this product. I will continue to purchase it, and would recommend it to anyone.   789. I read about this on a fashion web site.<br />I am not a terrible profuse sweater - probably average for a middle-aged male - but I usually don't like wearing undershirts, and my criteria for getting rid of a shirt i otherwise like is when the armpits become stained / discolored.<br />I had long read that this problem is not actually because of sweat, but rather because of deodorant/antiperspirant which I slather on (specifically the aluminum oxides in the antiperspirant getting into the fabric).<br />I had bought some really freakin expensive Robert Graham shirts, and I was eager to avoid this fate for them. So....<br />I researched the problem, and read on a couple of different forums that the solution is to use Sweat Block, which you put on at night once every 3-8 days (depending on your body chemistry / metabolism) and wash off in the morning, so it never comes in contact with your shirt.<br />Couple this with daily use of a non-aluminum / non-staining deodorant (I use Malin + Goetz Eucalyptus Deodorant) which now can be lightly applied rather than slathered on, and you are good to go with a non-staining solution.<br />BOTTOM LINE: I think this combo actually does a much better job of suppressing perspiration and odor than slathering on Mitchum, while at the same time there is no residue from the product to stain my shirts. Check back with me in 2 years, but so far in the 2 months I've been doing it I have not detected any sort of discoloration, staining, or white-chalky residue on any of my shirts, so it appears to be working great.

The other thing is that it does not do anything about odor. The recommendation from the company is that you buy a deodorant to go along with this antiperspirant. That means that you need to buy additional products to be happy with the results. I prefer an all-in-one solution myself. Given that this is relatively expensive, does not provide the full solution, does not last as stated and is not readily available in my local stores, I will look for another solution.

He's tried everything he could think of to no avail. This product has made him one very happy guy.<br /><br />The official FAQ for SweatBlock says this about using it on other body parts: \\"SweatBlock was developed specifically for underarm use, but many of our customers report success with SweatBlock elsewhere on the body such as head, neck, back, hands, and feet. The SweatBlock Satisfaction Guarantee is for underarm use only and it does not apply to other parts of the body. It is recommended that you consult a physician with further questions.\\"<br /><br />The active ingredient in this product is 14% aluminum chloride hexahydrate. An internet search for aluminum chloride hexahydrate turned up a link on WebMD that discusses the application requirements for feet when this product has been prescribed by a doctor for hyperhidrosis of the feet. Specifically, it's noted that the feet should be wrapped in plastic which is worn to bed at the end of the day after applying the medication and so on. My guess is that the product is meant to be prescription based, at least in part, because of the unique difficulties in applying the product anywhere but the underarms.<br /><br />For us, dabbing it onto the feet, especially between the toes and being sure to hit every part of the foot, then slipping the feet into 1 gallon plastic food bags like these: [[ASIN:B007EEFDJ8 Hefty Baggies Food Storage Bags 1 Gallon]] was a great way to accomplish the plastic wrapped foot. After the bag, we just put socks over the bags to keep them in place, then cut off the excess plastic about an inch above the edge of the sock.<br /><br />One application was enough to produce incredible results, but full action did not take place until a second application.<br /><br />I've never seen him smile about his feet before, and the other day he did. That was enough for me. I'd recommend it to anyone, and if you want to use it anywhere other than under the arms, check the internets for advice on how the active ingredient is applied when prescribed by a physician.enough for me. I'd recommend it to anyone, and if you want to use it anywhere other than under the arms, check the internets for advice on how the active ingredient is applied when prescribed by a physician.

  982. To give you some background, I'm a late 20 something male in great shape exercising between 3-7 days a week. I live in the city, Chicago to be exact. So when summer comes around, Lake Michigan blesses us with her humidity. Couple this with the fact that from April to September my only form of transit is my bike and it can get bad. I bike everywhere. Probably 1-2 hours a day biking, 2 hours a day playing volleyball, and 2 hours a day walking my energetic husky around the city. So believe me when I say this.<br /><br />I make it rain. And not in the 'make it rain with benjamins and strippers' way. Have you ever been in bed with someone and rain sweat on them? Gross, right? This stuff is amazing. It clogs the pipes I've been unable to stop leaking for the past 20 something years. You put it on at night (trust me, you want to do this), it irritates the hell out of your sweat gland, and it closes. So you 'sweat' but it just doesn't come out. I noticed this generally lasted 2-4 days for me. Not the full week claimed.<br /><br />When I first started using this I was near euphoric. But after awhile, it got extremely expensive. The way this stuff works is via a chemical called aluminium chloride. This chemical is what makes your 'antiperspirant' deodorant work in very low concentrations. Sweat Block contains a slightly higher concentration at 14%. They give you this tiny little cloth applicator that to be fair, is only supposed to cover your arm pits. Which it does. If you're like me and using it elsewhere...try ripping open the small packet this comes in. Inside is some plastic that you can rip open and get to the leftover solution. This gives you a bit more coverage.<br /><br />But if you really want to save a ton of money, you can get a giant bottle of this stuff in a 20% (vs. 14%) solution from your doctor. Any doctor. I paid $8 for a bottle of this stuff which will probably last me as long as $5,000 worth of Sweat Block.

It dries out the skin/pores but work like magic so I recommend! ***** Original review ***** These worked like magic for me :) Nothing you haven't read before by others. Now why -2 two stars? Just a week before I bought these I bought some candy (that had the 2-pack logo) and some Chapstick (also had 2-pack logo). This has the 8-pack logo. I was like &#34;wow! 8 boxes for $20?! Yes!&#34; But when I got it there was only one box with 8 packages INSIDE. If the logo is talking about whats INSIDE the box, then my candy should have been 240-pack (120 pieces in each box) and my Chapstick should have been a 4-pack, since each packaging had two in it and I got two packages. Contacted amazon, and they just kept repeating that it was in regards to what was inside the box... but yet had no answer when I pointed out my last purchases that had the logo and it was talking about actual physical number of boxes/packages. Very inconsistent! So if you've shopped and bought before based on that &#34;# pack&#34; logo then be careful, you only get ONE box for this product. Would I buy these again knowing I'm only getting one box? Maybe, when I thought I was getting a bunch I thought it was a great value. Now I only use a pack when I'm worried about sweat (used one a few nights before an interview and another for a mini vacation).

  989. Interesting product, although it's cons outweighed it's pros in my case. Product is easy to apply and upon waking in the morning I did not experience any sweat or even normal odor for the next several days. The downside for me however is that every spot that the product came in touch with broke out in a massive rash. Very red and raised skin. Almost like my pores were under attack. The information on the product indicates that deodorant can be used as well, however WebMD states that the active ingredient should not be mixed with other products like deodorants. It took approximately 2 weeks for the rash to go away after that first use. It did itch a bit but I restrained from scratching. Attempting to use aloe gel, topical antibiotics, etc. did not have any impact.<br /><br />Due to the rash I would not recommend this product. This is the only time I've ever experienced a negative reaction when using a product.

  1062. Hello everyone!<br /><br />I just want to give a few hints that may help those who have had issues with SweatBlock and products similar to it in the past.<br /><br />I've tried just about everything under the sun to get my underarm perspiration to what I'd considered normal, and they've all either failed terribly to do what they promised, or worked at the expense of extreme discomfort.<br /><br />I've discovered that the concentration of active ingredient in products like this can really truly irritate sensitive skin. An impressively sharp burning/prickly sensation that is quite painful at times has resulted from my use of it previously. Occasionally this irritation would lead to an actual rash, with highly irritated bumps in areas of my arm pit.<br /><br />This time, however, I tried it differently. I shower approximately an hour before each application, to provide ample time for my underarms to dry. I make sure to (very gently) clean and wash my underarms to remove all residual antiperspirant/deodorant that might interfere by blocking the application of the SweatBlock, and then jump out of the shower to dry (only applying slight pressure with the towel to dry my underarms, never wiping).<br /><br />When applying the product about an hour or so later, I make very sure to only &#34;blot&#34; with the prepackaged wipes, never rubbing or wiping with them at all. I've found that it is most definitely the agitation of the skin prior to and during application that causes the pain/discomfort.<br /><br />Lastly, I have seen directions on.other products that recommend you to put on a light shirt before going to bed. Do NOT do that. At least for me, I found that doing so introduced yet another somewhat abrasive element into the mix, even with extremely soft shirts. I simply go to sleep shirtless now.<br /><br />After trying this product once again using this method, the discomfort has gone from intolerable,to nothing more than a warm sensation. My perspiration problem has decreased respectively, and my confidence and comfort in social settings could not be better.<br /><br />It really is quite wonderful.<br />I hope this helps.

I used to have tennis ball sized pit stains half an hour after I get out of the shower, they are more like half the size of a golf ball now.

Now, my sister tried this product and it worked for only 1 day for her until she started getting sweat spots on her clothing. She sweats a great deal more than me in general so she was skeptical from the start. I assume this is why they tell you to apply before bedtime, so that you can sleep through this side-effect, but I can tell you that it would keep me up sometimes, and sometimes it would drive me so crazy I would attack my armpits viciously with my fingernails and scratch them up. This is why I encourage you to try it for yourself - it may work for you, it may not. The itching may drive you crazy, or it may be worth a few hours of discomfort to be able to confidently raise your arms for the next week. Give it a try.

I noticed my mineral salt deodorant still had aluminum in it, even if in natural form, but I was trying to get away from all aluminum, anything that would block my pores and stop me from sweating.<br />So I stopped that, too. I started using coconut oil on my pits, usually at night before bed. Just a teeny tiny bit is all you need, just enough to see a sheen on your fingers, and rub it in. Coconut oil is naturally antibacterial and antiviral. I only use this on my arm pits, not my face.<br />Sometimes I'll use a diluted tea tree oil/water/alcohol blend in a small spray bottle instead.<br /><br />It took a while for my body to adjust, but now, a few weeks since the switch, I never stink. My armpits smell awesome.<br />I sweat under there a little, just a little, but it never smells.<br />And here's the best part-- I no longer sweat all over my face. I think I had that problem because for years I had been plugging up my sweat glands in my arm pits. I don't know. Just telling you what worked for me.<br /><br />So, if you're suffering from extreme sweat, yes, Sweat Block will most likely stop it. But maybe start thinking about what else you can do, or why it's happening. I'd tried many over-the-counter anti-perspirants including Certain Dry (which worked to a certain extent, but not nearly enough); I've had to buy and throw out countless shirts because they were stained from both the sweat and the products meant to stop the sweat.<br />I found this product here on Amazon and was skeptical. I was thrilled to see that so many people seemed to have success with it, but had doubts whether it would actually work for me... I ultimately decided to give it a try just in case.<br /><br />I now live in San Diego and about a month ago tried Sweat Block for the first time. Even with the intense heat we've been having lately PLUS interviewing for -- and eventually starting -- a new job and all the stresses that entails, this product has been an absolute godsend since it's decreased my underarm sweating to almost nothing! Even on days when it was over 100 degrees and my back and chest were sweating like crazy, if I lifted my arms, there was just the smallest amount of sweat showing.<br /><br />I've noticed that the duration of its effectiveness varies (the first use seemed to last a full week, the second use lasted about 5 days, the third went back up to 6 days), but as long as it's still working, I'm a happy camper! The down side of the product is that it does irritate your sensitive underarm skin, particularly if you don't let it dry all the way as instructed.   1388. I've used Sweatblock for a little over a week now and I'm satisfied with it so far. I tried it on a whim and so far it's the only thing that has honestly stopped underarm sweating for long periods of time. Sweatblock advertises that it will keep you sweat-free for up to 7 days, but my personal experience is 4 days. I've seen reviews from people saying it worked for weeks after a single use. Ultimately, how you respond to the product, or not, will just depend on your body. I also suspect that it will work for longer periods of time if you're good about using it for a while, but I don't have enough experience with it to say for certain yet.<br /><br />A few tips/hints that I've learned:<br /><br />1. They stock this at Wal-Mart and it's cheaper than online (at least at my Wal-Mart).<br />2. Sweatblock instructions say it can take 2-3 days, using daily applications, to work. That was true for me.<br />3. DO NOT soak your underarms with this stuff, and DO NOT rub with the pad. This stuff will BURN if you get carried away. It usually starts burning a few hours after you apply it if you overdo it. I've learned that a little bit of this stuff goes a long way, so use sparingly.<br />4. If it starts burning, I found that aloe does a great job of fixing the problem. However, Sweatblock needs to be on your skin for at least 3-4 hours to work, so try to stick it out as long as you can before using aloe.<br /><br />One last thing, it's possible that a product like Certain Dri will work just as well as Sweatblock. Sweatblock is 14% aluminum chloride to Certain Dri's 12%. I'm going to use my current supply of Sweatblock and then try Certain Dri to see if it works just as well. However, for now, I'm enjoying being dry!enjoying being dry!

  1417. I have to admit, I have never written a review on any product I have purchased online. I am 46 yrs old and I have found no correlation to physical activity, the temperature of a room/outdoors, or anything I eat or drink. The sweating may start while I am just sitting in church. The only place I sweat is on my face (under my eyes and on my upper lip), head (along hairline - runs down my face) and on my neck (actually drips from my hair!). After having been to the doctor and having my thyroid and other labs checked, the excess sweating was eventually blamed on early menopause. The thing is, it is not a &#34;hot flash&#34; it is just plain old excessive sweating at random times. I have an executive level job, do a fair amount of presentations, and have interactions with Boards of Directors, etc. and I had a needed to find something that would work. I never know when the sweating will start - no stress, anxiety, or strenuous activity is needed.   1432. Where to begin. I don't normally post reviews but considering I've sufferered from hyperhidrosis since age 10 and what I've seen with this product, I felt I should comment. I could sweat in the middle of a blizzard and instead of enjoying my teens and college years, I held back because my hands and feet would drip; complete with pit stains that looked like you could wring out my shirt. As a girl this is emotionally devastating.<br /><br />Over the years I have tried prescription deodorants which felt like acid on my skin. I tried medication (from Mexico) for incontinence because one of the side effects was decreased sweating. Seven years ago I read about Endoscopic Thoracic Sympathectomy (ETS) surgery in which the sympathetic nerve is cut to treat hyperhidrosis. My insurance agreed to help pay for the surgery and it cured my hands and reduced my feet and armpits by 50%. About 4yrs ago I tried Botox to treat the remaining excess sweat. While it helped, it only lasted about 8mo and was very pricey and super painful. I hung my head and thought this was as good as it was going to get.<br /><br />I write this not to bore you or treat this like a blog, but to demonstrate how desperate I was to find a solution; no matter how painful.   1453. After trying every product I could purchase from the store (including but not limited to men's deodorant, women's deodorant, prescription strength \\"Certain Dry\\" and everything else in between), I finally turned to the internet in a last-ditch effort to wear any color other than black. I stumbled across this product and, although skeptical at first, I decided to give it a shot.<br /><br />Holey Sweet Drypits, Batman!<br /><br />All joking aside, this product is finally the first that actually worked, with good reason why. While most deodorant products contain 9-10% Aluminum Chloride at best, this product contains 14% (which is 2% more than Certain Dry). Granted, you have to follow the directions on the box specifically in order for it to work:<br /><br />1) Make sure your underarms are clean and dry. I used this product after I showered, but make sure not to shave right before or it will increase irritation (guys may need to clip their hair a little).<br />2) Put it on just before bed. This is the key step because you want to put it on when you have at least a 4-5 hour period of no sweating.<br />3) Walk around with your arms in the air until it drys completely.<br />4) Go to bed. If you like to sleep nice and warm, try to at least turn down the heating blanket, lower the thermostat, or remove a few layers of blankets so you stay cooler at night; Otherwise you may just sweat off the product before it gets a chance to work.<br />5) It will tingle and have a slight itch -- but this means it is working! I'm usually a light sleeper, but the one time that this itching did keep me up, I just took an ibuprofen tablet to block it out so I could sleep. No problemo, Amigo.<br /><br />Viola! Enjoy your ability to move your arms around, wear bight colored cotton shirts, and generally enjoy life again.<br /><br />Some notes from my experience directly:<br />- You can get at least 3 uses out of each wipe if it is properly stored back in its original pouch, but by the 3rd use it is not as effective as the first time.<br />- You can use this on your face (even though the directions say not to). I dabbed just under the corner of each of my eyes making sure NOT to get it too close where it could get INTO my eye. The next day my makeup did not run and make me look like a raccoon. Yay! Beware, however, that this product will make your skin extra dry, especially in sensitive areas such as the face. I would avoid using it on the face more than once a week.<br />- Speaking of dry, I did develop a minor rash. I used the product several nights within the same week and after about the 3rd go, the back of one of my arms had a very minor, slightly pink, dry rash. Immediately cleared up with a little lotion. Just be aware if you paint outside the lines that more sensitive areas may dry out more easily. However, I have yet to develop a rash on my actual arm pit and I haven't had any issue since that first time. I would say this one is more my fault than the fault of the product.<br />- The product becomes more effective with time. In my first week my sweating was so severe that, as the previous comment said, I had to use it three times to get the best effect. However, each week after that I only had to apply it on Sunday night to be fine for the rest of the week.<br />- I still used deodorant each morning! Although the product helps with sweating, it does not help with smell. I am not a smelly person, but I have a lovely deodorant that helps hydrate and keep my underarms smooth. Plus it smells like citrus!<br />- I run for long distances, and after using this product I did not sweat as heavily under my arms even after passing the 6 mile mark.<br />- I mixed products. Although this product is the most effective, it is also the most expensive. If I ever had a week that was particularly stressful/athletic and I needed a minor mid-week boost in my sweat treatment, I used a little certain dry since I still had a bottle I previously purchased. Although it wasn'teffective by itself, it seemed to work by being paired with Sweat Block.<br /><br />I hope this helps anyone who is interested in purchasing this product. Obviously, I highly recommend it and have given 5 stars according. I wish you the best of luck with your new sweat-free lifestyle.<br /><br />- The Artist Formerly Known as Sweatyeffective by itself, it seemed to work by being paired with Sweat Block.<br /><br />I hope this helps anyone who is interested in purchasing this product. Obviously, I highly recommend it and have given 5 stars according. I wish you the best of luck with your new sweat-free lifestyle.<br /><br />- The Artist Formerly Known as Sweaty

  1471. A year ago, I wrapped up a 6-month regiment of Accutane to address my severe acne. I noticed, however, that I began sweating...profusely. Sweating is apparently a very common after-effect of Accutane. Despite the amazing results I had from the medication in relation to my acne, it seemed like I stopped being self-conscious of one thing and started on another. I would start having underarm sweat as soon as I stepped out of the shower. Throughout the day, it wasn't uncommon for me to change my shirt at least once (to tell the truth, though, it was more like two or three times) because of the excessive amounts of underarm sweat I was dealing with. Many of the shirts I wear now have dark sweat stains on them. One of the most embarrassing things that happened was going wedding dress shopping. It was horrible because even though I only had on the dresses I tried on for a minute or two, the part of the dress under my armpits was wet with sweat. You can imagine my embarrassment. I was horrified because I realized I would be sweating even more on my wedding day, which reduced me to tears; I didn't want to feel gross on my wedding day and certainly didn't want to ruin my dress. I wanted to focus on what was important in a wedding, not worry about my armpits. I tried various antiperspirants, the most drastic of which was the day-and-night Certain Dri. I had absolutely no relief from the amount of sweating.<br /><br />I came across Sweat Block, and was very skeptical to buy into the hype. A towlette that you wipe on your armpits one night that solves your sweat problems for an entire week? I had my doubts. But I was also desperate and was willing to dish out $20 on something that had a chance of helping me - knowing I was running the risk of wasting $20 if the product didn't work. I'm so glad I made this purchase. The difference made has been incredible. My underarm sweat has been reduced substantially. I still sweat, but it's back to a normal amount. Now, let me give some advice to potential buyers.<br /><br />1. Don't feel you have to stick to the instructions. What I do is open one towlette and use it every night for seven days. I do that by keeping it in a ziploc bag. It's more effective that way.<br />2. Put it on AT NIGHT. The first time I used it, I used it in the morning and still had sweat problems. It needs to be applied when your sweat glands are less active.<br />3. Don't stop using your own deodorant or antiperspirant. This is meant to be used in addition to what you normally use.<br /><br />I would advise anyone who suffers from excessive sweat (whether as a natural condition or as the result of medication, as in my case) to use Sweat Block. I don't normally write reviews to promote a certain product because I know not everyone will like it the same way I do, but I made an exception here because I want others to know this isn't a gimmick. It truly has made a difference and I am a much more confident person today than before I started using Sweat Block - which was only a week and a half ago!! This truly is a worthwhile product and definitely worth the $20!

  1511. This is the BEST antiperspirant I have ever used, period... My wife saw it on the Rachel Ray show and told me about it. I have had a problem with sweat for many years for some unknown reason. I am not a nervous type of person, most would say quite the opposite if anything. I was always an active person and an avid workout nut and runner. I could run 4 miles and not even break a sweat. One day in my thirties, I just started to sweat a lot under my arms at almost anytime, without even exerting any physical activity. It is really embarrassing if you suffer from this condition they call it hyperhydrosis. It became worse and worse and I tried every antiperspirant I could find. Some helped a little, but the ones that worked the best would rub off on your shirts and get hard and show a white ring that is almost impossible to wash from your clothing.<br /><br /> I considered the medical solutions for the problem, which included injections and even surgical procedures to stop, kill, or trick the nerves that trigger the sweat glands. These procedures are costly and not always work as one would hope. Side effects can be nasty and even if the procedure stops your sweat under your arms, you could trigger the nerves to signal the sweat glands in another part of your body like your face, back, chest, hands, etc. I decided to try the Hydronics under arm machines that use moist pads to send electrical current into the nerves and somehow change the nerve signals. These machines work great, however they are very uncomfortable to wear and use. Depending on they severity of your problem, you may need to wear these for 15 to 30 minutes a day. They work great, but are a real pain in the neck to use and costly to maintain.<br /><br />Along came Sweat Block and it is easy to use along with inexpensive. It has controlled my sweat problems and makes me feel comfortable all day and it smells good too. It works for me and everyone I have told about it, you should give it a try, I don't think you'll be disappointed. Thank you Sweat Block and thank you Amazon for making easy to get. I only wish you would package it in larger quantity box.

But when it came to hyperhydrosis, I was to embarrassed to even tell my family. I HATED living with it. It really can effect your social life and definitely the clothes you have to wear. Then I came across this product when searching the web for hyperhydrosis solutions. I don't know why it took me so long to order. I finally couldn't take it anymore when I went to a party and could only where a black shirt and couldn't really hug girls cuz I didn't want them touching the huge sweaty shirt around my armpit. When it came in the mail I was so estatic. I tried it at night and when I woke up I felt fine. I usually do until a couple periods into school. I put on a light purple polo shirt (terrible if my sweating acts) and a black jacket incase (yes you could see the sweat stains through a thick colored jacket) I WENT THE WHOLE DAY WITH NO JACKET. when I went to the gym I always sweat no matter what. I wear cut offs on purpose and the spandex shirts that don't show sweat as much. I wore a grey cotton manktop and did chest. I sweated 90%less than regular which is fine because I'm pushing myself. Then I came back later in a green Mank and ran my ass off in basketball. My whole head and back and chest was soaked but not one sweat mark around my armpits. Unbelievable. I love this product and can't wait to wear all the colorful clothes and go out and not worry. Thank you sweat block!!!
  1515. Great. Just too expensive.

Amazingly, sweatblock worked as advertised for me, and kept my underarms dry for a full week (and longer after I had been using it for a few weeks). I'm enjoying wearing white again, being able to take off my jacket now, and just not worrying about underarm sweat. I will continue to use it, and would recommend it to anyone with the same problems.

  1524. I have been using SweatBlock for nearly a year now. Well, let's start with a little history. I am 26 now. I started sweating a little more than normal by the time I was about 14. By the time I was 16 I was sweating a good amount more, and by the time I was 18 I was sweating excessively. Like, a lot. I didn't discover this product until I was 25, so I spent almost my entire adult life ruining shirts and having obviously sweaty arm pits, embarrassed to be around people without a coat on. So back to present. I have been using SweatBlock since I was 25 and I have had no issues since about two weeks after I started using it. I have even gone as long as two weeks without an application and I would still be sweat free! Not much else to say on the topic. It's awesome, and Amazon has been a very reliable vendor.

  1530. At first I was skeptical about this product, but decided to try it and am SO glad I did. I did not purchase it for underarm sweat, but for forehead/face sweat after reading another another review. For some reason, I am ALWAYS hot and sweaty...like always. Inside or outside, even when others are cold and have jackets. And I'm not even doing anything that would cause a normal person to be hot and sweaty (if it helps, I'm a 26 year old female, average height and weight, a little overweight but average/normal, I don't exercise enough and I wouldn't say I'm totally in shape but I'm not totally out if shape if that makes sense). Being this hot and sweaty all the time is EMBARASSING. I definitely avoid public places if I can and have anxiety when I can't, I stopped doing my hair (straightening, etc) because I sweat while doing it and it's ruined before I'm done, and hats are definitely my best friend. I've lived like this for years. After happening upon this product and reading another review with forehead sweat issues very similar to mine, I decided to try it. I was only concerned it might irritate my skin (especially since I do have sensitive skin) but it didn't at all. It felt a little funny for maybe an hour after I first used it (a little tingly and my skin felt &#34;tight,&#34; which are normal side effects as warned by the directions). Nothing I would complain about and nothing that will prevent me from continuing to use SweatBlock religiously forever. It's been about 4 days and I still have not had my normal nasty sweaty forehead...it's amazing. Not only did I not sweat, my forehead wasn't greasy or oily. SweatBlock has changed my life...I now feel confident about being in public and am so excited to be able to straighten my hair and not just put it up in a messy bun everyday or wear a hat. Worth every penny.

  1534. I'm a very Sweaty Betty, hyperhidrosis that affects pretty much everywhere but my elbows. My body chemistry runs through medications (including Tylenol) faster than average and antiperspirants and deodorants aren't any different. I've tried prescription antiperspirants and found them as useful as the clinical strength OTC ones. I prefer Lady Speed Stick and Mitchum deodorants.<br /><br />These wipes are the best ADDITION to my antiperspirant/deodorant method. I don't use these alone, they don't protect against all sweating so body odor can definitely develop. If you're the average sweater, don't worry so much about layering another antiperspirant on top, I'm in the top 10% for sweating, I'm abnormal. I do recommend at least using a deodorant over it. This lasts through a few days (up to 3) of heavy sweating and about 5-6 days of normal activity.<br /><br />I apply this everywhere: my underarms, under my bust, my lower back, even parts of my face. I don't recommend applying it to your face if you have sensitive skin. I don't do that unless I'm going to be walking in 90+ heat for hours since it can be irritating.
  1535. Wow. I totally love this product! I've been a head sweater for years, and would drip all over the place from my face and scalp when everyone around me was bone dry. It's so embarrassing and I avoided many situations when I knew I'd be sweating. Purchased this product with high hopes after reading the reviews. I dab it on my face, and about 1 inch into my scalp, back of my neck, under my arms, under bra area, etc. and what a difference! I was in the Caribbean last week, and with sweat block I was sweating but not dripping everywhere like I should have been. I still feel as hot as ever, it doesn't change that, but the sweating has definitely decreased in a major way. I don't have any problem with rash, just some tightness on my face which goes away when I apply moisturizer in the morning. Seems to last 5-6 days for me, which is great. I do wish it were less expensive, but it's worth the price for the relief I get from it. Thank You Sweat Block!
  1536. It sort-of works, but not a whole lot more than just using a traditional anti-pirspirant. Applying it was rather easy, and while it did somewhat dry out my skin, it didn't create a rash or anything like that. I just have no idea how they expect 8 llittle damp towels to go for $20; the 'week's worth' of effectiveness is seriously overblown.

By day three my pits were like a desert and I felt confident shaking someone's hand without discreetly drying my stupid clammy palm on my jeans first. Ever since then I've applied once every 5 days and I'm golden! This stuff is a miracle for me. If you think you've tried anything and there's no over the counter help for you think again!

  1545. I have had good results with Sweat Block. I work inside without air conditioning and always felt my wardrobe was limited due to pit stains, now I am free to wear colors!
  1546. Let me start by saying that I admit my expectations or hopes for this product may have been a bit high. I do suffer from excessive perspiration or \\"cranial-facial hyperhydrosis\\". Mine is brought on by warmth or sudden increases in temperature. My job requires me to be outside most of the time. In the summer, just a short time in the sun under even light exertion would cause a fountain of sweat from my forehead & down my nose. In the winter, after being outside in to cold, walking into even a climate controlled room (68-73*F) would cause the waterworks to start. A co-worker once compared it to condensation on a can or bottle after bringing it out of the refrigerator into a warm room lol.<br /><br />Needless to say, this was embarrassing, as my job has me dealing with the public, and it was difficult to put my best foot forward. Much of the time, I'd be talking to people I'd never met & answering questions. You never get a 2nd chance to make a first impression. So it didn't matter how professional I was, or how much I knew, if I was a hot, sweaty mess & looked like I was about to die, it didn't inspire confidence. On top of that, once the sweating started, my self-consciousness & anxiety about it only made it worse: \\"am I sweating? Can they see me sweating? Is it more awkward to wipe my face or to just let it run?\\" I carry paper towels from the men's room in my pocket CONSTANTLY. For whatever reason though, I hate wiping off my sweaty mug in front of people. I'm not sure why; they know I'm sweating, I know I'm sweating, why not just deal with it? I'm telling you, social anxiety is no joke.<br /><br />So that's where this product comes in. Now to be fair, I knew my problem was bad, & I was desperate for a solution. So I also ordered Face Saver by Neat 3B (which I covered in a separate review). Didn't want to pin all my hopes & dreams to one product.<br /><br />So, for those unfamiliar with Sweat-Block, it's a wipe-based antiperspirant designed to eliminate excessive sweating. It's designed to be used on your underarms; in fact, the directions say to apply to your underarms ONLY. Oh well...<br /><br />Sweat-Block is designed to be applied at night before bed. The reason for this is because most people's sweat glands are not very active while they're sleeping, & it gives the product time to penetrate the skin & do it's magic, instead of being sweated right back off. The product states it will give you up to 7 days of protection with one application. So in a perfect world, 8 wipes would last about 2 months. Eh... I haven't seen results last that long myself. But then again, I'm also using it in a manner not indicated by the directions, so that's probably not Sweat-Block's fault.<br /><br />Application is simple; open the small package (it's like a wipe from a BBQ or chicken wing restaurant) and apply to the skin. Simply dab, or place the wipe on the skin, & press; DON'T RUB. It states that rubbing the wipe on the skin can cause excessive irritation. They're not kidding. I'm not sure how or why it makes a difference, but it does. Trust me. Once applied, go to bed & let it do it's thing. It dries fairly quickly, so no worries about it being rubbed off while you sleep. It's that easy.<br /><br />Now it is a strong antiperspirant, & states it can cause minor irritation (for which they recommend an anti-itch cream. But again, that probably applies to using the product on your underarms per the directions). Myself, I've never had too much of an issue with irritation from the product. When I wake up the next day after applying, my skin feels a little tight & drier than normal. I'd compare it to having a MILD sunburn. It doesn't hurt, per se. Just different.<br /><br />As far as applying goes, I read a description somewhere that the product possesses a \\"pleasant clove smell\\". That's an understatement. It smells like you opened a jar of cloves & stuck your nose in it. And you'll continue to smell it (because it's on your face) until you go to sleep. But fortunately, I haven't noticed the smell still hanging around in the morning. But if you don't like the smell, you may have a hard time with this product.<br /><br />As far as effectiveness, the product does what it says. It stops EXCESSIVE perspiration. It doesn't stop ALL perspiration. And I admit that perhaps my hopes were a little high. I knew I had a problem & was looking for a miracle. I don't believe that a product exists that will completely eliminate all sweating from my face. But this helped a lot. I never did get a full week of protection from it though. If I apply the product on Sunday night before the work week starts, I usually need another application Wednesday or Thursday night.<br /><br />I WILL say that the combination of Sweat-Block & Face Saver provides the most benefit. Face Saver is a gel designed to be applied in the morning. You simply apply a light layer of the gel to your face & let it dry. Easy enough. It gives me a little extra protection in case I missed an area with the wipe, or if that's the day the Sweat-Block application finally wears off. So, the first day or two after using the Sweat-Block, & the Face Saver every morning, tends to be my best days.<br /><br />All in all, I think this product lived up to it's claims. I think I was hoping for more, & therefore slightly disappointed that it wasn't the miracle I was looking for. But that's not the product's fault. You can't go buy apples & then be upset when you get them home because they're not oranges.<br /><br />***A word of warning***<br />Sweating is the body's natural way of cooling itself through evaporation. It's a necessary evil, not just a hassle. I've never been a sweaty guy in any area other than my face/head. That changed when I started using these products. Preventing the sweat from coming out on your face simply creates a dam; it's still got to go SOMEWHERE. I've started sweating in places I've never sweat before; my back (lower back especially, I can feel ittrickle down occasionally), feet, legs, palms. I even had droplets of sweat forming & running down my forearms at one point. Now I don't sweat all these other places at once, mind you. These are just the various locations it's popped up at different times. It's a small price to pay in my opinion, & I'd much rather do that since they're places that aren't typically visible. If you're going to try this or any other product to decrease facial sweating, just be aware of this potential consequence.
  1547. Finally! Something that really keeps you dry! I have suffered with sweating for years and had to wear two shirts just so no one would see me with wet underarms. I chose a profession where I'm close to clients so now I feel so confident being close to them. I won't need all my antiperspirants just my Sweatblock.   1567. I am 12 years post successful ETS surgery which reduced my plantar(feet) sweating by maybe 50%. In the past two years I have also had to take Oxybutynin 10mg(an anticholinergic)for overactive bladder, which reduced my sweating by an additional 30%. This still did not allow for me to wear the kind of shoes I would like to wear and I did still have unpredictable sweating. I decided to try this product because of the amazing reviews. So glad I did! I have not had any sweating in almost a week since I started using it.<br /><br />I do want to say that the morning after the first day I used it my feet did still sweat. I followed the suggestion to use it again another night and noticed a significant difference. However, I wear sneakers at work and noticed throughout the day that it felt like my toes were sweating in my socks. So the third night I dabbed the wipes on my toes, in between them and also the tips. No sweating since then, even with my sneakers on all day long!<br /><br />The same way ETS or anticholinergic meds are not for everybody these wipes will not work for everyone. Good luck to everyone who suffers from this horrible affliction in finding something that works for you.
  1568. Yes, I know that it's for the underarms, but I have issues with facial sweating. I live in LA so we have mainly dry heat. When I visit humid places, I sweat like a pig...it's embarrassing. So before my trip to Miami for a wedding, I decided to give this a shot. I tested it out a few weeks before just in case I broke out in a rash or something. I blotted it in my face and underarms and waited. So because I read the reviews, I knew that some people reported a tingling or stinging sensation. I didn't expect it to last quite so long and hurt so much. I know we all have different thresholds of pain, but it was uncomfortable, pokey and itchy. But I endured! Oh, and it smells funky, so the next time, I didn't dab under my nose. About 2 days later, I sat outside in the scorching sun eating lunch. My skin was a bit dry, but it was to be expected. I don't think I'll use this often just b/c I'm paranoid and don't know what it'll do to my face, but it's handy to have around when you know you might need it.

  1571. This is the best product I've tried that reduces sweat. I've been using it for six months now and went through the whole summer without worrying about underarm sweat or wetness. The first time I used this product, I applied the product in my underarm area and rubbed it to hard and ended up getting a rash, so I would recommend gently tapping it against the entire underarm area. I apply the product once a week at night after I shower and it works great. I tend to break out more during the winter (cold sweats) but after using this product, i haven't had any cold sweat breakouts.<br />FYI - I still wear deodorant daily.<br /><br />I would highly recommend trying this product.
  1572. I've been blessed with excessive underarm sweating that, over time, has taken its toll on my dress shirts. It actually led me to purchase my shirts in colors or with patterns that helped hide the wet areas that sometimes developed by mid morning. I had tried a number of extra strength, prescription strength, and other available anti-perspirants to no effect. I'd given up, and even tried underarm absorbent pads, which just became soggy messes. Then I gave this a try. It absolutely works - for me at least. I imagine its effectiveness may be based somewhat on your particular body chemistry, but for me, it worked 100% on the first try. It didn't just make the issue a little better - it eliminated it. Sure, I still perspire under my arms when it's warm out, but it is a normal level that does not soak or penetrate my clothing. I've found that I only need to apply this once every 2 weeks for it to remain effective. The worst side effect is a little bit of itching that sometimes happens the day after application. It usually is minor, if it happens at all (maybe 1 time out of ten).<br /><br />If you have similar issues, you must try this product. Maybe not quite &#34;life-changing&#34; but darn close.

Unfortunately I will have to return the remaining two boxes because this product does not work for me. I have severe hyperhidrosis of the hands/feet and to treat it I normally use prescription Hypercare solution(Aluminum Chloride Hexahydrate 20% and Anhydrous Ethyl Alcohol 93%). To extend the dryness even further I also do 6 to 8 - one hour treatments of Drionic which will keep my hands/feet dry for up to 4-6 weeks at a time. I wanted to try SweatBlock because applying it at bedtime is easier than using Hypercare solution(must use saran wrap and socks), and obviously much easier than using the Drionic device. Anyways, I used all 5 SweatBlock towellettes, 5 days in a row at bedtime and followed the instructions exactly, and unfortunately it did not stop the sweat on either my hands or feet. I'm not sure if there are certain levels of sweat that they could rate their product by, but obviously 14% Aluminum Chloride is not enough for me.<br />My suggestion: If you have severe hyperhidrosis this product may not work for you, but if you want to try anyways go buy the 5 pack at Walmart for $6.97. I gave 2 stars because obviously it works for some people but do take note that it is NOT prescription strength.

Apparently I took that nice gliding action from regular stick antiperspirant/deodorant for granted. So yes, it works, and I love the fact I don't have to worry about smearing white crap on my clothes. But, you're still stuck using a deodorant, and spraying that on your already ravaged pits is not pleasant. Given that it's somewhat pricy and irritates my princess pits I will not buy again, but people who truly sweat buckets could greatly benefit from this.
